speaker: Rob
text: Hello. This is 6 Minute English from BBC Learning English. I’m Rob.

speaker: Sam
text: And I’m Sam.

speaker: Rob
text: Have you seen my lottery ticket, Sam? I seem to have lost it somewhere…

speaker: Sam
text: Is this another one of your get-rich-quick schemes, Rob? People invent all kinds of ways to make a lot of money quickly and with little effort. Well, if you really want to get rich quick, maybe you should copy technology tycoon Elon Musk. Recently he invested one and a half billion dollars in the cryptocurrency, bitcoin.

speaker: Rob
text: Bitcoin has made some people very rich, very quickly, but as we’ll be hearing in this programme, it’s not without its critics.

speaker: Sam
text: Creating bitcoins, a process known as mining, uses huge amounts of electricity and green campaigners are now questioning bitcoin’s impact on global energy use.

speaker: Rob
text: But before we find out more, it’s time for my quiz question. What year was bitcoin first released? Was it…

speaker: Sam
text: I’ll go for b) 2015.

speaker: Rob
text: OK, we’ll find out the answer later in the programme.

speaker: Sam
text: In this programme, we are going to talk about bitcoin. The use of the virtual currency… it’s all very well for billionaires like Elon Musk, but what about the ordinary, average person – is bitcoin a good option for them?

speaker: Rob
text: Well, that’s exactly what BBC World Service programme Tech Tent wanted to find out by interviewing people in the street. Here’s what one bitcoin fan, Heather Delany, had to say:

speaker: risk-aversedip my toe pension plan.
text: I invested in bitcoin a number of years ago… with the initial investment of only around five dollars it meant that my risk was essentially the cost of a cup of coffee and a pastry, and as somebody who’s quite risk-averse when it comes to investment, it did allow me to dip my toe into bitcoin. Over time I was able to invest at various points as I really see bitcoin as more of a long-term investment and part of my overall pension plan.

speaker: risk-averse
text: Heather describes herself as risk-averse – she wants to avoid risks as much as possible.

speaker: dip a toe into
text: By only investing five dollars she was able to dip a toe into bitcoin - try doing something slowly and carefully to test whether she liked it.

speaker: pension plan -
text: Over time, Heather’s bitcoin investment became part of her pension plan - a financial plan funded by your salary to save money for when you retire.

speaker: Rob
text: So, everything seems to be working out for Heather.

speaker: Sam
text: But the recent buzz around bitcoin has also highlighted another, less positive side of the story - bitcoin’s environmental footprint.

speaker: Rob
text: Mining bitcoins, the complex process that creates new coins, uses a lot of electricity. Recent estimates show that bitcoin has now overtaken the entire annual electricity use of Argentina!

speaker: Sam
text: Michel Rauchs works at Cambridge University’s Centre for Alternative Finance which monitors bitcoin’s electrical consumption. Here he is in conversation with BBC World Service’s, Tech Tent:

speaker: put things   into perspectiveon standby
text: Bitcoin consumes just a colossal amount of electricity and now  whether that electricity expenditure is really worth the benefits, I think that really depends on how you value bitcoin itself… but just looking at the electricity consumption, I think we need to put things a bit  into perspective… so, on the one hand if you compare it to a country like Argentina, it’s just incredible, awe-inspiring… on the other hand, if you compare it to, for example, home appliances that are always on – on standby but not being used – in the US alone, that consumes twice as much electricity on a yearly basis as the entire bitcoin network.

speaker: put things into perspective
text: Michel thinks that to assess bitcoin’s energy use we must put things into perspective - find the true, objective value of something.

speaker: on standby
text: Comparing bitcoin’s energy use to a huge country like Argentina sounds monstrous. But looked at another way, bitcoin only consumes half the electricity used by all US televisions and other home appliances left on standby – which means powered on and ready to work when needed.

speaker: Sam
text: So maybe the best get-rich-quick scheme is to save money on your electricity bills by turning off your TV, Rob.

speaker: Rob
text: Well, it’s got to be easier than mining bitcoins – which reminds me….

speaker: Sam
text: …of your quiz question. You asked what year bitcoin was first released, 2009, 2015 or 2019. And I said b) 2015.

speaker: Rob
text: Which was the wrong answer, I'm afraid, Sam! It was first released in 2009.

speaker: get-rich-quick
text: So maybe we’d better keep buying lottery tickets. After all, it’s a pretty good get-rich-quick scheme – a way to make a lot of money, quickly.

speaker: risk-averse
text: Let’s recap the other vocabulary now. Someone who is risk-averse doesn’t like taking risks.

speaker: dip a toe into something
text: If you dip a toe into something, you test it out slowly and carefully to see how it feels.

speaker: pension plan
text: A pension plan is a way of saving money for your retirement.

speaker: Putting things into perspective
text: Putting things into perspective means assessing the real importance of something, often by comparing it to something similar.

speaker: on standby
text: Like comparing the energy use of bitcoin with the energy used by electrical appliances left on standby – ready to be used.

speaker: Sam
text: And that’s all we have time for.

speaker: Rob
text: Bye for now!

speaker: Sam
text: Bye bye!
